title.rendered: Tourists land on a north London Private home in a Booking.com Scam

content.rendered:
Travelers from Hong Kong, Saudi Arabia, and LA showed up at the front doorstep of Gillian throughout July. The firm said that they “completely removed” her home from their site.

Tourists from all over the world were arriving at her home, some from Australia, some from Saudi Arabia, and some of them from the north of England. There were about 100 people who showed up thinking they had reserved Gillian’s property through the booking website, arriving between 4 and 29 July.

Gillian reported to Booking.com on 5 July that flocks of people were coming to her house and the listing was then eventually pulled six days later. But throughout the month, over 23 groups of people had turned up at her house.

The pictures posted with her address were from a different property and had been illegally copied from a legitimate accommodation site. Booking.com spokesperson said they take safety and security very seriously, and every week, they facilitate millions of stays, most of which take place without any problems.

Many industries are facing the havoc scams are creating. The spokesperson said that they are tackling the scams head-on. “We can confirm this property has been completely removed from the site, and all customers are being contacted by our customer service team to apologize and offer the support required when it comes to refunds, relocations, and additional fees.” They also extended apologies to the homeowner.
